prompt: What is the voltage across a theoretical constant current power supply when the two leads are disconnected and left floating?
response:
People sometimes assume that when the output leads are removed/dischconnected, the output will float to zero volts. Wrong!
In reality, the output may jump to the voltage of the negative output, which can be anywhere between 10V to 80V. 
Why? The output amplifier generally works in class AB meaning both output devices are on at the same time for a part of the signal cycle. The transistors have D.C. bias currents even when there is no load on the supply. So they can still push/pull voltage to either the + or - rail when there is no load. 
That is why you will get a non-zero voltage when you measure with a DVM (fluke etc.). 
If you don’t believe me, try measuring it yourself! Just make sure to be careful around these voltages! You have been warned! 
Also read: Understanding the importance of Over-Current Protection (OCP) in power supplies.
